block.p: Germany's economy shrank in the fourth quarter of last year, the Government said yesterday. The economy shrank five-tenths of 1 percent from a quarter earlier, when growth was flat. Growth for all of 1995 was 1.9 percent, the Federal Statistics Office in Wiesbaden said.

The lackluster final two quarters could increase fears that Germany is entering a recession, although the Government insists that is not the case. "There can be no talk of a slide into a recession, nor of zero growth for 1996," the Economics Minister, Gunter Rexrodt, said in a statement. A day earlier, the Government said that joblessness last month hit a new postwar high of 4.27 million people, or 11.1 percent of the labor force.

Germany's economy shrank in the fourth quarter of last year, the Government said yesterday. The economy shrank five-tenths of 1 percent from a quarter earlier, when growth was flat. Growth for all of 1995 was 1.9 percent, the Federal Statistics Office in Wiesbaden said.

The lackluster final two quarters could increase fears that Germany is entering a recession, although the Government insists that is not the case. "There can be no talk of a slide into a recession, nor of zero growth for 1996," the Economics Minister, Gunter Rexrodt, said in a statement. A day earlier, the Government said that joblessness last month hit a new postwar high of 4.27 million people, or 11.1 percent of the labor force.
